ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION AND EMERGENCY RESPONSE POLICIES

The Sysco Food Services facility commenced operations in September 1998.  This facility has an emergency response plan in effect.  The Emergency Response Plan (Plan) is detailed in the Emergency Planning and Response section of this PSM/RMP document.  This Plan was designed to meet the following objectives:

1.)  To save lives.
2.)  To minimize and avoid injuries.
3.)  To protect the environment.
4.)  To minimize property damage.

Sysco Food Services maintains a safety committee whose members are the designated emergency coordinators for the facility.  The Plan provides the response organization and notification procedures, evacuation routes, ammonia health hazards, and mitigation procedures which will be implemented to respond effectively to emergency situations that may arise at the facility.  This Plan is reviewed and updated at least once per year.  This Plan will be reviewed and updated to ensure compliance with the PSM, RMP, and CalARP regulations, as well as to incorporate facility changes due to moving into a new facility.

STATIONARY SOURCE AND REGULATED SUBSTANCE

The Sysco Food Services ammonia refrigeration system startup occurred during the week of August 11, 1998 with Sysco Food Services personnel taking full responsibility for operating the entire facility in September 1998.  The facility is located at 12180 Kirkham Road, Poway, California 92064.  The facility was constructed in accordance with the most recently adopted Uniform Fire and Mechanical Codes. 

The ammonia refrigeration system uses 11,000 pounds of ammonia for warehouse cold storage.  It provides cooling for several cold storage areas: -100F freezer, 280F cooler, 500F cooler, 340F cooler, 400F cooler, 550F cooler, and 450F dock.  The majority of the system is located in the engine room including vessels and compressors.  The condensers are mounted on the engine room roof, the control box and diffusion tank are located outside t

he engine room, and all of the evaporators are located in their respective cold storage rooms/areas.

The refrigeration cycle begins with the transfer of high pressure liquid ammonia from the Thermosyphon Receiver to the Controlled Pressure Receiver (CPR), where the pressure is reduced from 181 psig to 103 psig.  The CPR serves as the main storage vessel for the system.  It also supplies liquid ammonia to the High Temperature Recirculator (HTR) which pumps the liquid to the evaporators (21) throughout the facility.  The liquid ammonia expands as it enters the various evaporator coils, reducing the temperature.  These evaporators are used to maintain low air temperatures for warehouse/dock storage in seven different zones.  As the air is chilled by the evaporators, the ammonia is vaporized and returned to the HTR, which maintains a liquid/vapor mixture of ammonia at 27 psig.

The HTR also routes the liquid from the CPR to the Low Temperature Recirculator (LTR), which further reduces the pressure of the ammonia to 1.3 psig.  The LTR supplies liquid ammonia to the freezer evaporators (6) and collects the resulting vaporized ammonia.  The Booster Compressor pulls this low pressure ammonia vapor from the LTR and discharges higher pressure vapor to the HTR.  The High Stage Compressors (2) pull this booster discharge from the HTR and further compress it.  This high stage discharge (hot gas) from the High Stage Compressors is piped to the condenser, where the ammonia is converted back to high pressure liquid and recycled to the Thermosyphon Receiver.  The auto purger periodically purges the system of non-condensibles collected in the CPR and the condensers.  The system also has a dilution tank (into which the relief header vents), which maintains a water level at 70% capacity to allow for ammonia charge. 

HAZARD ASSESSMENT SUMMARY

Worst Case Release
The worst case release for this facility was that of the maximum quantity of ammonia that can be stored in the largest vesse

l in 10 minutes.  The largest vessel is designed to hold the entire charge of 11,000 pounds.  No mitigation measures were incorporated into the release rate calculation.  The most pessimistic meteorological conditions were used: 1.5 meters/second wind speed and F stability. The facility is located in an urban setting.  This scenario has a very low probability of occurrence and is considered to be the worst case.  The INPUFF dispersion model was used to determine the maximum downwind distance to 200 ppm.  The release reaches off-site and may affect population receptors.  No environmental receptors were affected by this potential release.

Alternative Release
The alternative release scenario is a leak in a high pressure vapor (hot gas) line (on the roof of the facility) feeding an evaporator.  To be conservative, a 0.25" diameter hole in the 2.5" hot gas line will be modeled.  The release rate is 8 lbs/min based on the hole size.  This release is similar to that of the worst case release in that the release will be pressurized ammonia vapor.  As the hot gas defrost cycle does not operate continuously (only on a timer basis), the duration of the release scenario is limited to the defrost cycle time length, but to be conservative, a release time of 60 minutes will be used.  This scenario is mitigated by a procedure; an operator visually inspects the roof piping runs and the evaporator coils periodically.  The meteorological conditions used were 3.0 meters/second wind speed and D stability. The facility is located in an urban setting.  The INPUFF dispersion model was used to determine the maximum downwind distance to 200 ppm.  The release reaches off-site and may affect population receptors.  No environmental receptors were affected by this potential release.


ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION PROGRAM AND CHEMICAL-SPECIFIC PREVENTION STEPS

The Sysco Food Services facility was designed and constructed in accordance with the 1994 Uniform Mechanical Code which specifically ou

tlines requirements for the safe operation of ammonia refrigeration systems.  These safety features include a water diffusion tank, ammonia sensors in the engine room, and automatic shut down systems.  In addition, the majority of the ammonia is maintained inside the engine room or on the engine room roof (condenser).

In addition to the Uniform Mechanical Code, the facility will operate in accordance with the International Institute of Ammonia Refrigeration (IIAR) guidelines.  In particular, the IIAR Bulletin 110, "Startup, Inspection, and Maintenance of Ammonia Refrigeration Systems."

FIVE YEAR ACCIDENT HISTORY

There have been no ammonia-related accidents at this facility since the system startup in August 1998.

Sysco Food Services maintains a safety committee whose members are the designated emergency coordinators for the facility. PLANNED CHANGES TO IMPROVE SAFETY

The Process Hazard Analysis and Seismic Risk Assessment provided the mitigation measures outlined below to improve safety at the Sysco Food Services facility located at 12180 Kirkham Road in the city of Poway,

California.  All recommendations listed were implemented on or before July 1998.

Process Hazard Analysis

R01  Ensure that there are audible and visual alarms at the engine room doors to alert employees upon ammonia detection.

R02  Ensure that the emergency kill switches are adequately located in relation to the exit doors from the engine room.

R03  Establish procedure to replace/recertify all relief valves every five years or any time a valve vents.

R04  Ensure that there are eye wash/safety shower stations that can be reached easily from all typical maintenance locations.  This could include portable eye wash bottles for operations on the roof.

R05  Develop an emergency response plan that includes the response actions for employees.  Decide whether employees will be instructed to respond to ammonia leaks.

R06  Invite emergency responders (local Fire Department) for initial and periodic informational sessions regarding the ammonia system.  Coordinate response efforts with these designated responders.

R07  Establish a procedure to contain a liquid ammonia spill.  Use an absorbent material to assist in the disposal process.

R08  Periodically test high level shut down switches on recirculating vessels.

R09  Ensure that the ammonia operator is trained in and follows the oil draining procedures.

R10  Follow manufacturer's recommendations regarding maintenance on all equipment including recirculating pumps, compressors, and condensers.

R11  Maintain a daily log sheet that is completed by an operator to establish trends to detect any system deviation in system behavior.

R12  Establish a water treatment plan for condensers.  Consider subcontracting this service.

R13  Label the box for fire department use only.  Place a system process flow diagram on the inside door of the control box and label each incoming line as to its origin.

R14  Ensure that the correct permits, if necessary, are obtained from the sewer district for operation of the auto purger.

R15  En

sure that two people are present during an oil drain on the oil pots associated with the High Temp Recirculator and Low Temp Recirculator.

R16  Ensure that the area is cordoned off (with cones, signs, tape, etc.) during ammonia delivery operations.  Identify the emergency shut off switch to the delivery truck driver prior to the ammonia charging.

R17  Install eye wash/safety shower stations inside the engine room.

R18  Establish a maintenance procedure to ensure the safety of the operators working on the condenser located on the roof of the engine room.

R19  Calibrate ammonia detectors based on the manufacturer's recommendations, but not less often than once per year.

R20  Install wind socks or other wind direction indicators that can be seen from all sides of the facility.

R21  Designate primary and secondary evacuation assembly locations based on the prevailing wind directions.

R22  Assign responsibility for roll call during evacuation.  Ensure that the supervisors understand that they will be required to account for the whereabouts of operators and truck drivers on site during an evacuation.

R23  Complete the Human Factor Engineering checklist at such time when the construction of the facility is finished and the ammonia system is operational.

R24  Review Emergency Response checklist (contained in Appendix C) after the completion of the facility's emergency response plan.


Seismic Risk Assessment

S01  Add appropriate seismic bracing to the Thermosyphon Receiver.

S02  Add anchor bolts to the Auto Purger.

S03  Complete seismic bracing for overfeed piping in the Engine Room.

S04  Attach ammonia piping on the roof to each Fixed Pipe Support Detail (B/R-07) with appropriate pipe clamps.
